node.text: Francesco Zonin talks about the challenges facing Zonin1821 as it celebrates its 200th anniversary.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Maule, Chile. May be a black-and-white image of child, standing, indoor and brick wall.

node.text:
Stomping into another week of harvest...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
At González Bastías winery in the Maule Valley of Chile, everything is done by hand and without machine, from farming to vinifying. And when it comes to crushing those grapes, these ladies do it in rhythm too.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
(The platform they are standing on is made of bamboo and called a zaranda, with the juice flowing down through it directly into a fermenting vat.)⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Another cool image captured by our #WSfeaturedphotographer Leigh-Ann Beverley, who's been giving us a peek into the harvest work that most folks don't get to see.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Cheers to your Monday!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @bonafideproductions⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #harvestwork

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Dry Creek Valley AVA. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
As we head into the waning days of summer we continue to celebrate the faces of harvest work with our #WSfeaturedphotographer, Leigh-Ann Beverley. She captured this image at dawn in Ridge's vineyards located in the Dry Creek Valley.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Harvesting is typically done before daybreak (and sometimes at night) to avoid the heat of the day to bring in the fruit in as fresh a condition as possible. And it's done by hand.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Just a reminder that more gets done before 9 a.m. for your bottle of wine than gets done all day...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Cheers to the harvesters!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @bonafideproductions⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #harvestwork

node.text:
Charging into harvest like...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Winemaker Sam Bilbro of Idlewild Wines is shown here, busy chucking bins full of grapes around at his Wild Ruth Ranch in the Yorkville Highlands. Another fun image caught by Leigh-Ann Beverley, our #WSfeaturedphotographer for August. We gave her a simple theme: 'harvest work' and she's been crushing it all month long...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
See what we did there?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Cheers to the weekend!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @bonafideproductions⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #harvestwork

node.text:
Portugal's Douro Valley is the home of Port, one of the world's great dessert wines. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If you survived Y2K and loaded up on the 2000s upon release, you'll want to know how the wines are doing. Senior Editor @jmolesworth1 has written up his analysis based on a retrospective tasting of the vintage.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If you didn't stock up on 2000s back then, well don't worry. Port is also arguably the greatest value in world class, age worthy wines. Older vintages on the secondary market often sell for less than the current releases.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for the full scoop on one of Port's great vintages that is now hitting its stride.⁠⁠
⁠⁠.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSeducate #winemaps #Portugal #port #VintagePort

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Wine Spectator on August 24, 2021 tagging @monteriocellars.

node.text:
Who's ready to crush their day?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Our #wsfeaturedphotographer for the month of grabbed this shot of sommelier/restauranteur-turned-winemaker Patrick Cappiello getting up close and personal with some grapes for his Monte Rio Cellars project.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
You just can't make wine without getting your hands dirty...and that's the kind of work we love.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @bonafideproductions⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #harvestwork

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Wine Spectator with @grahams_port, @taylorsportwine, @fonsecaport, @churchills_port, @niepoortvinhos, @symingtonfamilyestates, and @quintadonoval_official. May be an image of bottle and indoor.

node.text:
As the year 2000 approached, there was hype piled on hype. This included the Y2K fears of computer crash–induced mass hysteria and a market eager for ageworthy wines from 2000 to mark the turn of the millennium. Y2K didn’t pan out. But the vintage did.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Among the highlights from 2000 is Vintage Port, which checked in with a classic quality vintage. A recent blind tasting of 18 different 2000 Vintage Ports showed the wines to be progressing very well as they start to hit their stride. Of the wines tasted, all earned outstanding scores of 90 points or better on Wine Spectator’s 100-point scale, with five bottlings earning classic scores of 95 points or better.⁠⁠⁠
⁠⁠
You don't need Port tongs to check our our retrospective either. Just click the linkin.bio for Senior Editor @jmolesworth1's analysis on the vintage along with his tasting notes and scores based on a recent blind tasting.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
And don't forget to always pass the decanter to the left...!⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
📸: @jmolesworth1⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSeducate #VintagePort #tastingnotes #WineWednesday

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Stony Hill Vineyard with @jaimeemotleywines. May be an image of 1 person and drink.

node.text:
You know what they say about all work and no play...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Winemaker Jamiee Motley, now at Napa's Stony Hill Vineyard, made sure there was some fun while loads of grapes were coming in. She's taking a sip of Champagne after her husband and fellow winemaker Nico Cueva of Haynes Vineyard decided to smudge her face with some just-stomped Cabernet grapes...now it's a party!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Photographer Leigh-Ann Beverley captured this image. She's our #WSfeaturedphotographer for the month of August and we've been posting her images with the theme of 'harvest work'.⁠ We hope you're enjoying them as much as we are...⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Cheers to slinging crushed grapes!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @bonafideproductions⁠⁠
.⁠⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Wine Spectator. May be an image of bottle and indoor.

node.text:
Did you know all our wine ratings are based on blind tastings?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Removing inherent bias based on a wine producer's reputation or the price of the wine is critical to providing objective, independent reviews. And Wine Spectator is the only major wine publication that adheres to this tasting methodology.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for more on how we taste and review wines at Wine Spectator.⁠⁠
⁠⁠.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
⁠#winespectator #wine #WSeducate #winetasting #blindtasting #tastingnotes

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Diamond Mountain District, Calistoga. May be an image of 1 person and nature.

node.text:
Why is it that folks in the wine industry are so happy?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This harvester at Teachworth Winery on Napa's Diamond Mountain is part of our August series 'harvest work', as captured by our current #WSfeaturedphotographer Leigh-Ann Beverley.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
As for the 'why', it must be the sun, fresh air and close contact with Mother Nature. Plus the thought of a good glass of wine at the end of the day.

Cheers to the weekend…!
⁠⁠
⁠📸: @bonafideproductions⁠⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Chassagne-Montrachet. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
When it comes to making wine, sometimes you have to put your back into it.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
For fans of white Burgundy, the 2018 whites from the region’s famous terroirs represent the fifth year in a row of fine vintages, showing opulent profiles and soft structures, with the best retaining freshness and good acidity.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for a complete report on the vintage from our Senior Editor @bsandersonwine. And when you're reading, don't forget to tip your glass in homage to the folks who brought those grapes in from the vineyard...⁠⁠
⁠⁠.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
